column1: An Astro component file uses the {{c1::.astro::file extension}} extension and separates logic from markup using {{c2::--- frontmatter delimiters::syntax}}.
column2:
---
const data = await fetch(...);
---
<div>{data}</div>
React components are just .jsx/.tsx files without this separation. Frontmatter is inspired by Markdown.

column1: The frontmatter section in Astro runs {{c1::once at build/render time::execution timing}} on the server, while the template section defines {{c2::static HTML output::purpose}}.
column2: All imports and logic in frontmatter execute server-side only. The template generates HTML. React components execute on both server and client, Astro's frontmatter never touches the client.

column1: Astro template syntax is {{c1::JSX-like::similarity}} but uses class instead of {{c2::className::difference}}.
column2: <div class="container"> vs React's className. Astro is closer to HTML, React is closer to JavaScript. Less context switching for traditional web developers.

column1: In Astro frontmatter, you can use {{c1::top-level await::async feature}} without an async function wrapper.
column2: const data = await fetch(url); works directly in frontmatter. React requires useEffect with async functions or React Server Components. Simpler code for data fetching.

column1: Astro component props are accessed through {{c1::Astro.props::global object}} instead of function parameters.
column2: const { title } = Astro.props; vs React's function Component({ title }). More explicit but less concise than React's approach.

column1: To type Astro component props, define an {{c1::interface Props::TypeScript pattern}} and destructure with type annotation.
column2:
interface Props { title: string; }
const { title }: Props = Astro.props;
Less integrated than React's FC<Props> but achieves the same type safety.

column1: The default slot in Astro is defined with {{c1::<slot />::element}} and receives content passed as children.
column2: <slot /> renders children content. Similar to React's {children} prop, but uses web component slot syntax instead.

column1: Named slots in Astro use {{c1::name attribute::slot syntax}} like <slot name="header" /> to allow multiple content areas.
column2: Consumers specify slot with <div slot="header">. More flexible than React's single children prop. Multiple named areas without props drilling.

column1: Slot fallback content in Astro is defined {{c1::inside the slot element::fallback syntax}} and renders when no content is provided.
column2: <slot>Default content</slot> shows "Default content" if slot is empty. Similar to React's {children || 'Default'} but cleaner syntax.

column1: Astro supports both {{c1::HTML comments::comment type}} with <!-- --> and {{c2::JSX comments::comment type}} with {/* */} in templates.
column2: Use whichever style you prefer. HTML comments appear in source, JSX comments don't. React only supports JSX-style comments in JSX.

column1: Import statements in Astro frontmatter can import {{c1::other Astro components, framework components, and regular modules::import types}}.
column2:
import Header from './Header.astro';
import Button from './Button.jsx';
Mix Astro and framework components freely. Identical import syntax to React.

column1: Layout components in Astro typically wrap content with a {{c1::<slot />::composition pattern}} and provide consistent structure across pages.
column2:
Common pattern: <header></header>
<slot />
<footer></footer>
Similar to React layout components but uses slots instead of children prop.

column1: Page components in Astro go in the {{c1::src/pages/::directory}} directory and automatically become routes.
column2: src/pages/about.astro becomes /about route. Same file-based routing as Next.js Pages Router, but .astro extension instead of .jsx.

column1: Use {{c1::Astro components::component choice}} for static content without interactivity, and framework components when you need {{c2::state or effects::interactivity}}.
column2: Astro components are simpler and ship no JavaScript. Framework components support useState, useEffect, etc. Choose based on interactivity needs, not familiarity.

column1: JavaScript expressions in Astro templates use {{c1::single curly braces::syntax}} like {variable}, same as JSX.
column2: <h1>{title}</h1> works identically to React. Arrays can be mapped the same way. Familiar syntax reduces learning curve.

column1: The class:list directive in Astro allows {{c1::dynamic class names::utility}} from arrays or objects.
column2:
<div class:list={['base', { active: isActive }]} />
Similar to classnames library in React but built-in. Cleaner than template literals for conditional classes.

column1: Astro components can accept and render {{c1::framework components as props::composition}}, enabling flexible composition patterns.
column2: Pass React components to Astro layout as props, then render with client directives. More flexible than React's limited children prop pattern.

column1: All code in Astro frontmatter is {{c1::stripped from the client bundle::security}}, making it safe to use environment variables and secrets.
column2: const secret = import.meta.env.SECRET_KEY; never reaches browsers. React components must carefully separate server/client code to avoid leaking secrets.

column1: Astro components are {{c1::not reactive::behavior}} - they render once and don't re-render on prop changes.
column2: No useState, no re-renders, no lifecycle. Pure rendering function called once. For reactive updates, use framework components with client directives.

column1: The Astro.props object is {{c1::read-only::mutability}} and cannot be modified within the component.
column2: Props are immutable, just like React. Difference is accessing via Astro.props instead of function parameters. Encourages one-way data flow.
